message_text: Paper Title: Fixed-Time and Prescribed-Time Consensus Control of Multiagent Systems and Its Applications: A Survey of Recent Trends and Methodologies Paper Abstract: Fixed-time and prescribed-time consensus control can bring an explicit estimate of the settling time without dependence on initial conditions, which is important in providing control engineers a priori system information. This article aims at presenting a survey of recent trends and methodologies of fixed-time and prescribed-time consensus control in multiagent systems. First, some typical fixed-time consensus results are reviewed. Despite the advantage in deriving a fixed settling time bound, fixed-time consensus controllers usually result in a conservative estimate of the bound and a large magnitude of initial control input, which in turn show the necessity of designing prescribed-time consensus controllers. Second, characteristics and controller design of (practical, respectively) prescribed-time consensus are provided in detail. Particularly, representative time-varying function-based controllers are presented, by which (practical, respectively) consensus can be achieved in prescribed time. Third, applications of fixed-time and prescribed-time consensus control in mobile robots and smart grids are illustrated in case studies. Finally, several challenging issues in prescribed-time consensus control are discussed for future research. "contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.) "survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work) task - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding) method - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction) data - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus) artifact - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9) tool - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope) concept - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory) other - Entities that don't fit above categories uses - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks) proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS: - ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work) - CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new) { "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey", "triples": [ { "name": "Wikipedia Article Title", "relation": "uses|proposes", "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other", "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...", "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)" } ] } FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool: CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do. 1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field. 2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation. 3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia. 4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm") - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes) - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/) - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters 5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py 6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes. When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter: WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"]) This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains. Begin now.

Web search results for query: "multiagent systems"

Here's a summary of the search results on multiagent systems:

## Definition and Basics

A multi-agent system (MAS) is a computerized system composed of multiple interacting intelligent agents.(no content)Multi-agent systems can solve problems that are difficult or impossible for an individual agent or a monolithic system to solve.

## Key Characteristics

Agents in multi-agent systems have several important characteristics including autonomy (agents are at least partially independent and self-aware), local views (no agent has a full global view), and decentralization (no agent is designated as controlling).

## Applications and Uses

Applications where multi-agent systems research may deliver an appropriate approach include online trading, disaster response, target surveillance and social structure modelling.

## Recent Developments

With advancements in large language models (LLMs), LLM-based multi-agent systems have emerged as a new area of research, enabling more sophisticated interactions and coordination among agents.

## Related Fields

Multi-agent reinforcement learning (MARL) is a sub-field of reinforcement learning that focuses on studying the behavior of multiple learning agents that coexist in a shared environment.

The field has a strong research community, with established conferences and journals dedicated to multiagent systems research.

## Search Results for "Mobile Robots"

I've performed a web search on mobile robots and found comprehensive information. Here's what I discovered:

### Definition and Overview
A mobile robot is an automatic machine that is capable of locomotion.(no content)Mobile robots have the capability to move around in their environment and are not fixed to one physical location.

### Applications
Mobile robots are deployed across various sectors:
- **Healthcare**: Hospitals have been using autonomous mobile robots to move materials for many years.
- **Logistics**: Warehouses have installed mobile robotic systems to efficiently move materials from stocking shelves to order fulfillment zones.
- **Security and Industry**: Mobile robots are also found in industrial, military and security settings.

### Components
The components of a mobile robot are a controller, sensors, actuators and power system.

### Research Focus
Mobile robots are also a major focus of current research and almost every major university has one or more labs that focus on mobile robot research.

### Historical Example
Shakey the Robot was the first general-purpose mobile robot able to reason about its own actions.

The search results provide detailed information on various aspects of mobile robotics, including navigation systems, specific robot models, and their diverse applications across industries.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "control systems settling time"

Links: [{"title":"Settling time - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Settling_time"},{"title":"Overshoot (signal) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Overshoot_(signal)"},{"title":"Dead-beat control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dead-beat_control"},{"title":"Step response - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Step_response"},{"title":"Control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_theory"},{"title":"Proportional–integral–derivative controller - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Proportional–integral–derivative_controller"},{"title":"Transient response - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Transient_response"},{"title":"Rise time - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rise_time"},{"title":"Lead–lag compensator - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lead–lag_compensator"},{"title":"Control engineering - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_systems_engineering"}]

Based on the web search results, here's comprehensive information about settling time in control systems:

## Definition

In control theory, the settling time of a dynamical system, such as an amplifier or other output device, is the time elapsed from the application of an ideal instantaneous step input to the time at which the amplifier output has entered and remained within a specified error band.

## Role in Control Systems

Settling time is one of the key time-response specifications of a control system, along with rise time and peak overshoot.(no content)Settling time is closely associated with overshoot, indicating how long it takes for the output to reach steady state.

## Improving Settling Time

Derivative action in PID controllers predicts system behavior and thus improves settling time and stability of the system. Additionally, system design parameters can be tuned to optimize settling time, though there are often trade-offs with other performance metrics.

## Mathematical Formulation

For specific system types, settling time can be calculated mathematically. For a second order, underdamped system, the settling time depends on the damping ratio and natural frequency of the system.

Settling time is a fundamental metric used by control engineers to evaluate and design systems that need to respond quickly and accurately to changes in their operating conditions.

Based on the web search results, here's comprehensive information about settling time in control systems:

## Definition

In control theory, the settling time of a dynamical system, such as an amplifier or other output device, is the time elapsed from the application of an ideal instantaneous step input to the time at which the amplifier output has entered and remained within a specified error band.

## Role in Control Systems

Settling time is one of the key time-response specifications of a control system, along with rise time and peak overshoot.(no content)Settling time is closely associated with overshoot, indicating how long it takes for the output to reach steady state.

## Improving Settling Time

Derivative action in PID controllers predicts system behavior and thus improves settling time and stability of the system. Additionally, system design parameters can be tuned to optimize settling time, though there are often trade-offs with other performance metrics.

## Mathematical Formulation

For specific system types, settling time can be calculated mathematically. For a second order, underdamped system, the settling time depends on the damping ratio and natural frequency of the system.

Settling time is a fundamental metric used by control engineers to evaluate and design systems that need to respond quickly and accurately to changes in their operating conditions.

Based on the search results, here's information about "consensus control":

## Consensus Control in Multi-Agent Systems

Consensus control is an area of research at the intersection of systems theory and graph theory that studies how a group of agents—such as robots, sensors, or decision-makers—interacting over a network can reach a common decision or estimate through local rules and information exchange.(no content)In multi-agent systems, the consensus problem involves ensuring that all agents eventually agree on a certain quantity, despite starting with potentially different initial values.

### Key Aspects

The consensus protocol, or agreement protocol, defines the rules of interaction that lead to convergence.(no content)Consensus control has applications in areas such as physiological systems, gene regulatory networks, large-scale energy systems, and coordinated control of autonomous vehicle fleets on land, in the air, or in space.(no content)Related coordination problems include the rendezvous problem, synchronization, flocking, and formation control, which often rely on similar mathematical foundations and are studied under the broader umbrella of cooperative control.

In essence, consensus control addresses how distributed systems of autonomous agents can collectively arrive at decisions or reach agreement without centralized control.

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about smart grids:

## Definition and Overview

The smart grid is an enhancement of the 20th century electrical grid, using two-way communications and distributed so-called intelligent devices. More specifically, the term smart grid is most commonly defined as an electric grid that has been digitized to enable two way communication between producers and consumers.

## Key Features and Benefits

Research is mainly focused on three systems of a smart grid – the infrastructure system, the management system, and the protection system.(no content)A smart grid includes a variety of operation and energy measures: Advanced metering infrastructure, smart distribution boards and circuit breakers integrated with home control and demand response, load control switches and smart appliances, renewable energy resources, including the capacity to charge parked electric vehicle batteries or larger arrays of batteries recycled from these, or other energy storage.(no content)The potential benefits from a smart grid include increased reliability, more efficient electricity use, better economics, and improved sustainability.

## Advantages for Renewable Energy

The improved flexibility of the smart grid permits greater penetration of highly variable renewable energy sources such as solar power and wind power.

## Historical Development

The concept of a smart grid began to emerge in the early 2000s.(no content)The first official definition of Smart Grid was provided by the Energy Independence and Security Act of 2007 (EISA-2007), which was approved by the US Congress in January 2007.

## Global Implementation

In the 21st century, some developing countries like China, India, and Brazil were seen as pioneers of smart grid deployment.

message_text:
1. [completed] Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. [completed] List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. [completed] For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. [completed] Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name: Use the Wikipedia article title, relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes), entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other, wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/), relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. [in_progress] Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. [pending] If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.
